clinical_study.official_title: Veterans With Diabetes Mellitus: Improving Physical Activity and Participation

lead_sponsor.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

clinical_study.source: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to investigate if the investigators can improve physical activity and social participation level among Veterans with diabetes.

detailed_description.textblock: Physical activity is the cornerstone of good diabetes management, and yet effective physical activity intervention is not available. The investigators developed a lifestyle intervention based on individual's home activity patterns. The goal of the study is to test the efficacy of this intervention among Veterans with diabetes in a randomized-controlled trial. In addition to physical activity, the investigators will also assess if the intervention will improve social participation among Veterans.

primary_outcome.description: Home physical activity measurement and survey questions

other_outcome.description: 6 minute walk, gait speed, timed up and go

arm_group.description: OT-led counseling based on home activity pattern
Usual activity during the study. At the end of the study, will receive OT-led counseling

intervention.description: At the end of the study, will receive OT-led counseling

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Veterans
- Aged 60 years or older
- Has Type 2 diabetes mellitus
- Able to operate accelerometer
- Competent to consent to the study
- No dementia diagnosis
- Ambulatory with or without assistive device
- English-speaking
- Community living (i.e., not a nursing home resident)
- Not physically active on a regular basis (less than 150 minutes of moderate or vigorous physical activity per week)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Medically unstable
- Hospitalized within the last 6 months
- 2 or more days of complete bed rest in the last month
- hemiplegia or limb amputation
- Self-reported illness or conditions that would impair the cooperation with the study team or the ability to complete the study
- work involved in shift schedule
- current enrollment of a physical activity program
- replacement of hip or knee within the last 6 months.
- Parkinson's disease
- frequent falls
